notes: Acute sinusitis usually viral and self-limiting; antibiotics rarely shorten illness. Provide TARGET RTI self-care leaflets and emphasise analgesia, hydration, and nasal saline rinses.
Exclude pregnant individuals under 16 years, immunosuppressed patients, chronic sinusitis (>12 weeks) and those requiring urgent ENT review (orbital involvement, severe swelling, CNS symptoms).
Use shared decision-making to balance high-dose intranasal corticosteroid vs antibiotic supply; record severity, duration (>10 days), and patient preference.
If providing fluticasone, counsel on correct nasal spray technique, potential epistaxis, and off-label status for sinusitis (supported by NICE).
Safety-net for red flags: periorbital cellulitis, visual disturbance, severe frontal headache, drowsiness, or neurological signs—refer immediately.

decisionTree.title: Consider the risk of deterioration or serious illness
decisionTree.question: Does the patient have complications or high-risk features?

complications: Severe facial pain with neurological symptoms
escalation: Ophthalmic involvement, cranial nerve palsy, altered mental status

yes.title: Onward referral
actions: Consider NEWS2 prior to calling emergency services.
Do not supply under PGD when complications suspected.

no.title: Clinical diagnosis
no.question: Diagnose acute sinusitis based on one or more of: nasal blockage/congestion OR nasal discharge/postnasal drip PLUS one of facial pain/pressure, hyposmia, or cough (children).

yes.title: Symptom duration
yes.question: Has the patient had symptoms for ≤10 days?

yes.title: Supportive care
actions: Reassure that sinusitis usually lasts 2–3 weeks and resolves without antibiotics.
Offer analgesics, nasal saline rinses, steam inhalation, hydration, and rest.
Advise to revisit if symptoms worsen or persist beyond 10 days.

no.title: Symptoms >10 days without improvement
no.question: Do symptoms show little improvement after 10 days?

no.title: Self-care and pain relief
actions: Continue supportive management and reassess if deterioration occurs.
Encourage adherence to nasal hygiene and analgesics.

yes.title: Gateway point
yes.question: Does the patient have ≥2 features suggesting acute bacterial sinusitis?

no.title: Consider high-dose intranasal corticosteroid
actions: Offer fluticasone furoate 27.5 micrograms (two actuations twice daily) for 14 days if symptoms moderate/severe and patient prefers non-antibiotic option.
Provide self-care advice and reassess if no improvement in 7 days.
no.followUp: Pharmacist review if symptoms persist or worsen.

yes.title: First-line management
yes.question: Shared decision: start high-dose nasal steroid for 14 days (with analgesia). If unsuitable/ineffective consider antibiotics.

steroidGuidance: Discuss benefits of intranasal corticosteroid as first option.
Reserve antibiotics for severe or non-responsive cases.

yes.title: Fluticasone furoate nasal spray

dose.≥12 years: Two actuations (27.5 mcg each) per nostril twice daily

plus: Off-label for sinusitis; supported by NICE.
Show correct spray technique; avoid directing at nasal septum.
Warn about possible epistaxis or local irritation.
yes.followUp: If no improvement within 7 days of treatment start, consider antibiotic assessment.

no.title: Antibiotic consideration
no.question: Does the patient meet criteria for antibiotics after steroid failure/intolerance?

yes.title: Reported penicillin allergy
yes.question: Is there a confirmed penicillin allergy?

yes.title: Erythromycin (pregnant with penicillin allergy)
formulations: Oral suspension 125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL
plus: Take with food to minimise GI effects.
Advise to seek care for jaundice or severe diarrhoea.
yes.followUp: Return if no improvement after 3 days.

no.title: Clarithromycin or Doxycycline

dose.Doxycycline (adults only): 200 mg stat then 100 mg once daily

plus: Assess interactions (macrolides with statins/QT drugs; doxycycline contraindicated in pregnancy/under 12 years).
no.followUp: Review if symptoms worsen or fail to improve after treatment.

no.title: Phenoxymethylpenicillin (first line antibiotic)
plus: Continue analgesia and nasal care during antibiotic course.
Advise to complete 5-day course and seek review if no improvement.
no.followUp: Return if symptoms worsen or fail to improve after completion.

no.title: Monitor after steroid
actions: Continue steroid course and self-care; antibiotics not indicated yet.
Review in 3–5 days if symptoms worsen or patient remains very symptomatic.

no.title: Acute sinusitis less likely
actions: Consider allergic rhinitis, migraine, dental pathology, or chronic sinusitis.
Refer or treat according to alternative diagnosis and provide safety-netting.
